item.title: Crypto Thieves Steal Solana via Hidden Chrome Extensions
item.description: <p>Socket researchers identified a malicious Chrome extension that manipulates Raydium swaps.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-crypto-thieves-steal-solana/">Crypto Thieves Steal Solana via Hidden Chrome Extensions</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: AI Malware, Voice Bot Flaws, Crypto Laundering, IoT Attacks — and 20 More Stories
item.description: Hackers have been busy again this week. From fake voice calls and AI-powered malware to huge money-laundering busts and new scams, there’s a lot happening in the cyber world. Criminals are getting creative — using smart tricks to steal data, sound real, and hide in plain sight. But they’re not the only ones moving fast. Governments and security teams are fighting back, shutting down fake
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: New phishing domains point to a campaign from the notorious Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters collective

item.title: Key provisions of the UK Cyber Resilience Bill Revealed
item.description: Shona Lester, head of the Cyber Security and Resilience Bill team within the UK government, outlined some of the provisions that should be included in the future law

item.title: Gainsight Expands Impacted Customer List Following Salesforce Security Alert
item.description: Gainsight has disclosed that the recent suspicious activity targeting its applications has affected more customers than previously thought. The company said Salesforce initially provided a list of 3 impacted customers and that it has "expanded to a larger list" as of November 21, 2025. It did not reveal the exact number of customers who were impacted, but its CEO, Chuck Ganapathi, said "we
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Shai-Hulud v2 Spreads From npm to Maven, as Campaign Exposes Thousands of Secrets
item.description: The second wave of the Shai-Hulud supply chain attack has spilled over to the Maven ecosystem after compromising more than 830 packages in the npm registry. The Socket Research Team said it identified a Maven Central package named org.mvnpm:posthog-node:4.18.1 that embeds the same two components associated with Sha1-Hulud: the "setup_bun.js" loader and the main payload "bun_environment.js." The
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Meet Rey, the Admin of ‘Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters’
item.description: A prolific cybercriminal group that calls itself "Scattered LAPSUS$ Hunters" made headlines regularly this year by stealing data from and publicly mass extorting dozens of major corporations. But the tables seem to have turned somewhat for "Rey," the moniker chosen by the technical operator and public face of the hacker group: Earlier this week, Rey confirmed his real life identity and agreed to an interview after KrebsOnSecurity tracked him down and contacted his father.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs
item.category: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Digital Fraud at Industrial Scale: 2025 Wasn't Great
item.description: Advanced fraud attacks surged 180% in 2025 as cyber scammers used generative AI to churn out flawless IDs, deepfakes, and autonomous bots at levels never before seen.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Cyber-Attack Disrupts OnSolve CodeRED Emergency Notification System
item.description: A cyber-attack claimed to be the resposibility of INC Ransom group and targeting the OnSolve CodeRED platform has disrupted emergency notification and exposed user data across the US

item.title: 'Dark LLMs' Aid Petty Criminals, But Underwhelm Technically
item.description: As in the wider world, AI is not quite living up to the hype in the cyber underground. But it's definitely helping low-level cybercriminals do competent work.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Prompt Injections Loom Large Over ChatGPT's Atlas Browser
item.description: It's the law of unintended consequences: equipping browsers with agentic AI opens the door to an exponential volume of prompt injections.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: How Malware Authors Are Incorporating LLMs to Evade Detection
item.description: Cyberattackers are integrating large language models (LLMs) into malware, running prompts at runtime to evade detection and augment their code on demand.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Enterprises Aren't Confident They Can Secure Non-Human Identities (NHIs)
item.description: More than half of organizations surveyed aren't sure they can secure non-human identities (NHIs), underscoring the lag between the rollout of these identities and the tools to protect them.
item.dc:creator: Don Tait

item.title: UK Report Proposes Liability For Software Provider Insecurity
item.description: A new report from the UK Business and Trade Committee has called for accountability of software providers for cyber flaws amid rising attack costs

item.title: Qilin Ransomware Turns South Korean MSP Breach Into 28-Victim 'Korean Leaks' Data Heist
item.description: South Korea's financial sector has been targeted by what has been described as a sophisticated supply chain attack that led to the deployment of Qilin ransomware. "This operation combined the capabilities of a major Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) group, Qilin, with potential involvement from North Korean state-affiliated actors (Moonstone Sleet), leveraging Managed Service Provider (MSP)
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: FBI Warns of $262M Losses from Account Takeover Fraud in 2025
item.description: The FBI reports over $262m in losses from account takeover schemes since January 2025, as cybercriminals impersonate financial institutions to steal data and funds

item.title: Huawei and Chinese Surveillance
item.description: <p>This quote is from <a href="https://www.mcnallyjackson.com/book/9780593544631"><i>House of Huawei: The Secret History of China&#8217;s Most Powerful Company</i></a>.</p> <blockquote><p>&#8220;Long before anyone had heard of Ren Zhengfei or Huawei, Wan Runnan had been China&#8217;s star entrepreneur in the 1980s, with his company, the Stone Group, touted as &#8220;China&#8217;s IBM.&#8221; Wan had believed that economic change could lead to political change. He had thrown his support behind the pro-democracy protesters in 1989. As a result, he had to flee to France, with an arrest warrant hanging over his head. He was never able to return home. Now, decades later and in failing health in Paris, Wan recalled something that had happened one day in the late 1980s, when he was still living in Beijing...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Gainsight Cyber-Attack Affect More Salesforce Customers
item.description: The CEO of the customer support platform said “a handful of customers” saw their data exposed after the breach

item.title: When Your $2M Security Detection Fails: Can your SOC Save You?
item.description: Enterprises today are expected to have at least 6-8 detection tools, as detection is considered a standard investment and the first line of defense. Yet security leaders struggle to justify dedicating resources further down the alert lifecycle to their superiors. As a result, most organizations' security investments are asymmetrical, robust detection tools paired with an under-resourced SOC,
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Webinar: Learn to Spot Risks and Patch Safely with Community-Maintained Tools
item.description: If you're using community tools like Chocolatey or Winget to keep systems updated, you're not alone. These platforms are fast, flexible, and easy to work with—making them favorites for IT teams. But there’s a catch... The very tools that make your job easier might also be the reason your systems are at risk. These tools are run by the community. That means anyone can add or update packages. Some
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Chrome Extension Caught Injecting Hidden Solana Transfer Fees Into Raydium Swaps
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a new malicious extension on the Chrome Web Store that's capable of injecting a stealthy Solana transfer into a swap transaction and transferring the funds to an attacker-controlled cryptocurrency wallet. The extension, named Crypto Copilot, was first published by a user named "sjclark76" on May 7, 2024. The developer describes the browser add-on as
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: HashJack Indirect Prompt Injection Weaponizes Websites
item.description: A new vulnerability dubbed “HashJack” could enable attackers to booby trap websites when they interact with AI browsers

item.title: London Councils Hit By Serious Cyber “Incidents”
item.description: At least three London local authorities are dealing with a major cybersecurity incident

item.title: RomCom Uses SocGholish Fake Update Attacks to Deliver Mythic Agent Malware
item.description: The threat actors behind a malware family known as RomCom targeted a U.S.-based civil engineering company via a JavaScript loader dubbed SocGholish to deliver the Mythic Agent. "This is the first time that a RomCom payload has been observed being distributed by SocGholish," Arctic Wolf Labs researcher Jacob Faires said in a Tuesday report. The activity has been attributed with medium-to-high
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Iran Exploits Cyber Domain to Aid Kinetic Strikes
item.description: The country deploys &quot;cyber-enabled kinetic targeting&quot; prior to — and following — real-world missile attacks against ships and land-based targets.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: FBI Reports $262M in ATO Fraud as Researchers Cite Growing AI Phishing and Holiday Scams
item.description: The U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has warned that cybercriminals are impersonating financial institutions with an aim to steal money or sensitive information to facilitate account takeover (ATO) fraud schemes. The activity targets individuals, businesses, and organizations of varied sizes and across sectors, the agency said, adding the fraudulent schemes have led to more than $262
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Advanced Security Isn't Stopping Ancient Phishing Tactics
item.description: New research reveals that sophisticated phishing attacks consistently bypass traditional enterprise security measures.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Beek

item.title: Cheap Hardware Module Bypasses AMD, Intel Memory Encryption
item.description: Researchers built an inexpensive device that circumvents chipmakers' confidential computing protections and reveals weaknesses in scalable memory encryption.

item.title: DPRK's FlexibleFerret Tightens macOS Grip
item.description: The actor behind the &quot;Contagious Interview&quot; campaign is continuing to refine its tactics and social engineering scams to wrest credentials from macOS users.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Crime Rings Enlist Hackers to Hijack Trucks
Years of JSONFormatter and CodeBeautify Leaks Expose Thousands of Passwords and API Keys
item.description: New research has found that organizations in various sensitive sectors, including governments, telecoms, and critical infrastructure, are pasting passwords and credentials into online tools like JSONformatter and CodeBeautify that are used to format and validate code. Cybersecurity company watchTowr Labs said it captured a dataset of over 80,000 files on these sites, uncovering thousands of
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Smishing Triad Impersonation Campaigns Expand Globally
item.description: A cluster of fraudulent domains impersonating Egyptian providers have been identified linked to Smishing Triad operations

item.title: With Friends Like These: China Spies on Russian IT Orgs
item.description: State-linked hackers stayed under the radar by using a variety of commercial cloud services for command-and-control communications.

item.title: As Gen Z Enters Cybersecurity, Jury Is Out on AI's Impact
item.description: Despite possibly supplanting some young analysts, one Gen Z cybersecurity specialist sees AI helping teach those willing to learn and removing drudge work.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: JackFix Uses Fake Windows Update Pop-Ups on Adult Sites to Deliver Multiple Stealers
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers are calling attention to a new campaign that's leveraging a combination of ClickFix lures and fake adult websites to deceive users into running malicious commands under the guise of a "critical" Windows security update. "Campaign leverages fake adult websites (xHamster, PornHub clones) as its phishing mechanism, likely distributed via malvertising," Acronis said in a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: New FlexibleFerret Malware Chain Targets macOS With Go Backdoor
item.description: A new macOS malware chain using staged scripts and a Go-based backdoor has been attributed to FlexibleFerret, designed to steal credentials and maintain system access

item.title: 'JackFix' Attack Circumvents ClickFix Mitigations
item.description: A new ClickFix variant ratchets up the psychological pressure to 100 and addresses some technical mitigations to classic ClickFix attacks.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Four Ways AI Is Being Used to Strengthen Democracies Worldwide
item.description: <p>Democracy is colliding with the technologies of artificial intelligence. Judging from the audience reaction at the recent <a href="https://www.coe.int/en/web/world-forum-democracy">World Forum on Democracy</a> in Strasbourg, the general expectation is that democracy will be the worse for it. We have another narrative. Yes, there are risks to democracy from AI, but there are also opportunities.</p> <p>We have just published the book <a href="https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262049948/rewiring-democracy/">Rewiring Democracy: How AI will Transform Politics, Government, and Citizenship</a><em>.</em> In it, we take a clear-eyed view of how AI is undermining confidence in our information ecosystem, how the use of biased AI can harm constituents of democracies and how elected officials with authoritarian tendencies can use it to consolidate power. But we also give positive examples of how AI is transforming democratic governance and politics for the better...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Zapier NPM Hack Unleashes Self-Spreading Worm Attack
item.description: <p>Each infected version has the ability to automatically spread itself to thousands of other repositories without any human intervention whatsoever.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-zapier-npm-hack/">Zapier NPM Hack Unleashes Self-Spreading Worm Attack</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: ToddyCat’s New Hacking Tools Steal Outlook Emails and Microsoft 365 Access Tokens
item.description: The threat actor known as ToddyCat has been observed adopting new methods to obtain access to corporate email data belonging to target companies, including using a custom tool dubbed TCSectorCopy. "This attack allows them to obtain tokens for the OAuth 2.0 authorization protocol using the user's browser, which can be used outside the perimeter of the compromised infrastructure to access
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 3 SOC Challenges You Need to Solve Before 2026
item.description: 2026 will mark a pivotal shift in cybersecurity. Threat actors are moving from experimenting with AI to making it their primary weapon, using it to scale attacks, automate reconnaissance, and craft hyper-realistic social engineering campaigns. The Storm on the Horizon Global world instability, coupled with rapid technological advancement, will force security teams to adapt not just their
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Hackers Hijack Blender 3D Assets to Deploy StealC V2 Data-Stealing Malware
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new campaign that has leveraged Blender Foundation files to deliver an information stealer known as StealC V2. "This ongoing operation, active for at least six months, involves implanting malicious .blend files on platforms like CGTrader," Morphisec researcher Shmuel Uzan said in a report shared with The Hacker News. "Users unknowingly
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Influencers in the crosshairs: How cybercriminals are targeting content creators
item.description: Social media influencers can provide reach and trust for scams and malware distribution. Robust account protection is key to stopping the fraudsters.

item.title: CISA Warns of Active Spyware Campaigns Hijacking High-Value Signal and WhatsApp Users
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Monday issued an alert warning of bad actors actively leveraging commercial spyware and remote access trojans (RATs) to target users of mobile messaging applications. "These cyber actors use sophisticated targeting and social engineering techniques to deliver spyware and gain unauthorized access to a victim's messaging app,
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ShadowRay 2.0 Turns AI Clusters into Crypto Botnets
item.description: A threat actor is leveraging a flaw in the Ray framework to hijack AI infrastructure worldwide and distribute a self-propagating cryptomining and data theft botnet.

item.title: Critical Flaw in Oracle Identity Manager Under Exploitation
item.description: The exploitation of CVE-2025-61757 follows a breach of Oracle Cloud earlier this year as well as a recent extortion campaign targeting Oracle E-Business Suite customers.

item.title: Infamous Shai-hulud Worm Resurfaces From the Depths
item.description: This campaign introduces a new variant that executes malicious code during preinstall, significantly increasing potential exposure in build and runtime environments, researchers said.

item.title: Vision Language Models Keep an Eye on Physical Security
item.description: Advancements have expanded that models' reasoning capabilities to help protect employees' physical safety.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: Is Your Android TV Streaming Box Part of a Botnet?
item.description: On the surface, the Superbox media streaming devices for sale at retailers like BestBuy and Walmart may seem like a steal: They offer unlimited access to more than 2,200 pay-per-view and streaming services like Netflix, ESPN and Hulu, all for a one-time fee of around $400. But security experts warn these TV boxes require intrusive software that forces the user's network to relay Internet traffic for others, traffic that is often tied to cybercrime activity such as advertising fraud and account takeovers.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: Request for Comments: PCI Key Management Operations (KMO) v1.0 Standard
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: New Fluent Bit Flaws Expose Cloud to RCE and Stealthy Infrastructure Intrusions
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered five vulnerabilities in Fluent Bit, an open-source and lightweight telemetry agent, that could be chained to compromise and take over cloud infrastructures. The security defects "allow attackers to bypass authentication, perform path traversal, achieve remote code execution, cause denial-of-service conditions, and manipulate tags," Oligo Security said in
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Second Sha1-Hulud Wave Affects 25,000+ Repositories via npm Preinstall Credential Theft
item.description: Multiple security vendors are sounding the alarm about a second wave of attacks targeting the npm registry in a manner that's reminiscent of the Shai-Hulud attack. The new supply chain campaign, dubbed Sha1-Hulud, has compromised hundreds of npm packages, according to reports from Aikido, HelixGuard, JFrog, Koi Security, ReversingLabs, SafeDep, Socket, Step Security, and Wiz.&nbsp;The trojanized
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Fortinet Exploit, Chrome 0-Day, BadIIS Malware, Record DDoS, SaaS Breach & More
item.description: This week saw a lot of new cyber trouble. Hackers hit Fortinet and Chrome with new 0-day bugs. They also broke into supply chains and SaaS tools. Many hid inside trusted apps, browser alerts, and software updates. Big firms like Microsoft, Salesforce, and Google had to react fast — stopping DDoS attacks, blocking bad links, and fixing live flaws. Reports also showed how fast fake news, AI
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: IACR Nullifies Election Because of Lost Decryption Key
item.description: <p>The International Association of Cryptologic Research&#8212;the academic cryptography association that&#8217;s been putting conferences like Crypto (back when &#8220;crypto&#8221; meant &#8220;cryptography&#8221;) and Eurocrypt since the 1980s&#8212;had to <a href="https://www.iacr.org/news/item/27138">nullify</a> an online election when trustee Moti Yung lost his decryption key.</p> <blockquote><p>For this election and in accordance with the bylaws of the IACR, the three members of the IACR 2025 Election Committee acted as independent trustees, each holding a portion of the cryptographic key material required to jointly decrypt the results. This aspect of Helios&#8217; design ensures that no two trustees could collude to determine the outcome of an election or the contents of individual votes on their own: all trustees must provide their decryption shares...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Chinese DeepSeek-R1 AI Generates Insecure Code When Prompts Mention Tibet or Uyghurs
item.description: New research from CrowdStrike has revealed that DeepSeek's artificial intelligence (AI) reasoning model DeepSeek-R1 produces more security vulnerabilities in response to prompts that contain topics deemed politically sensitive by China. "We found that when DeepSeek-R1 receives prompts containing topics the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) likely considers politically sensitive, the likelihood of it
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ShadowPad Malware Actively Exploits WSUS Vulnerability for Full System Access
item.description: A recently patched security flaw in Microsoft Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) has been exploited by threat actors to distribute malware known as ShadowPad. "The attacker targeted Windows Servers with WSUS enabled, exploiting CVE-2025-59287 for initial access," AhnLab Security Intelligence Center (ASEC) said in a report published last week. "They then used PowerCat, an open-source
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: China-Linked APT31 Launches Stealthy Cyberattacks on Russian IT Using Cloud Services
item.description: The China-linked advanced persistent threat (APT) group known as APT31 has been attributed to cyber attacks targeting the Russian information technology (IT) sector between 2024 and 2025 while staying undetected for extended periods of time. "In the period from 2024 to 2025, the Russian IT sector, especially companies working as contractors and integrators of solutions for government agencies,
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Matrix Push C2 Uses Browser Notifications for Fileless, Cross-Platform Phishing Attacks
item.description: Bad actors are leveraging browser notifications as a vector for phishing attacks to distribute malicious links by means of a new command-and-control (C2) platform called Matrix Push C2. "This browser-native, fileless framework leverages push notifications, fake alerts, and link redirects to target victims across operating systems," Blackfog researcher Brenda Robb said in a Thursday report. In
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISA Warns of Actively Exploited Critical Oracle Identity Manager Zero-Day Vulnerability
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Friday added a critical security flaw impacting Oracle Identity Manager to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation. The vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-61757 (CVSS score: 9.8), a case of missing authentication for a critical function that can result in pre-authenticated
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Deja Vu: Salesforce Customers Hacked Again, Via Gainsight
item.description: In a repeat of similar attacks during the summer, threat actors affiliated with the ShinyHunters extortion group used a third-party application to steal organizations' Salesforce data.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: LINE Messaging Bugs Open Asian Users to Cyber Espionage
item.description: In a potential gift to geopolitical adversaries, the encrypted messaging app uses a leaky custom protocol that allows message replays, impersonation attacks, and sensitive information exposure from chats.
item.dc:creator: Tara Seals

item.title: Cloudflare's One-Stop-Shop Convenience Takes Down Global Digital Economy
item.description: Even the most advanced systems like Cloudflare can fall victim to software issues and become a global point of failure, Dr. David Utzke argues, adding that the recent outage should be a warning for enterprises.
item.dc:creator: Dr. David Utzke

item.title: Hack the Hackers: 6 Laws for Staying Ahead of the Attackers
item.description: A new security framework responds to a shift in attackers' tactics, one that allows them to infiltrate enterprises &quot;silently&quot; through their own policies.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: More on Rewiring Democracy
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Grafana Patches CVSS 10.0 SCIM Flaw Enabling Impersonation and Privilege Escalation
item.description: Grafana has released security updates to address a maximum severity security flaw that could allow privilege escalation or user impersonation under certain configurations. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-41115, carries a CVSS score of 10.0. It resides in the System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM) component that allows automated user provisioning and management. First
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
